stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the Overworld/Yoshi Village hub area (paths, flowers, fruit baskets, campfire/fireplace, bamboo garden) while also diving into a major live debugging session with Sauraen about F3DEX3 occlusion planes and future microcode optimizations. The stream also includes candid strategic planning for a potential Nintendo takedown (dual builds with/without Mario) and early notes for a late-game ‘mechanic’ boss fight timeline placement.
stream_context.significance_reason: A substantial real-time technical collaboration with Sauraen establishes the project’s performance roadmap (occlusion planes, triangle commands, potential material/texture-load deferral), alongside a concrete legal-risk mitigation plan (custom character + dual release) and forward planning for a major boss encounter.

findings.summary: Kaze reframes the Overworld village aesthetic as ‘Yoshis built this’ rather than overtly Yoshi-branded architecture: bridges and structures should feel primitive and functional, not themed set dressing.

Yoshi Village is made to feel ‘lively’ via small environmental storytelling props: fruit baskets (intended to be filled with apples), patches of flowers, and a central gathering area (campfire/fireplace) with seating logs.
Kaze tests and likes the immediate readability improvement from adding a path decal; it becomes a key compositional tool to make the space feel welcoming and guided.
findings.quote: The path makes this so much better. Right off the bat.

findings.summary: He prioritizes building the level first and optimizing later, stating he’s not currently “trying to save any performance,” but expects Sauraen’s occlusion planes to unlock much larger scenes once working.

Occlusion planes are currently non-functional in Kaze’s build despite verified view-projection math; he wants them working as step one because his render code has grown large (he cites ~a quarter of render code devoted to occlusion plane factor computation).

In a live call, Sauraen explains occlusion planes in three steps: (1) per-vertex behind-plane checks on the RSP (skipped in NOC builds), (2) converting a chosen world-space plane to 12 short coefficients (4 screen-space lines + depth plane) including clipping/rotation logic, and (3) selecting which candidate occlusion plane to use via heuristics tuned on an OOT scene.

Kaze and Sauraen attempt a controlled debug by manually injecting ‘include everything’ occlusion-plane coefficients and verifying the data reaches RSP memory (DMEM), but occlusion still doesn’t occur; Sauraen leaves to retest on his side, suspecting either coefficient mistakes or a regression/assumption mismatch.

Sauraen proposes a tradeoff discussion: keeping ‘triangle snake’ commands (very low triangle memory traffic, but higher relative RSP cost now that baseline RSP is faster) versus introducing an SP three-triangles command to regain instruction memory headroom for other features.

Sauraen pitches a potentially large RDP win: defer expensive texture-load/material RDP command blocks until the moment a triangle using that material actually needs to draw (via a pointer to an RDP-command list executed on-demand). Kaze reacts that his scenes already include off-screen/hidden materials being loaded (e.g., ropes) and estimates this could save ‘a couple hundred microseconds’ in some views, but toolchain re-export costs and ‘material bleeding’/state-unknown risks are concerns.

Kaze outlines a contingency plan: while Biobak is reworking levels, the team will work on replacing Mario with a custom character and ship two versions (with Mario and without) so a Nintendo takedown can be countered by directing players to the non-Mario build.
findings.quote: So we can release both a version with Mario and a version without Mario. So that when Nintendo, on like week 1, is on our door and is like, take this down, we can be like, fine, but there's another. Fuck you.

findings.summary: Zeina supplies new textures (and is building Yoshi houses), which Kaze treats as a dependency for populating the village with Yoshis; he also expects Biobak to ‘go over’ his models and reduce texture clutter (e.g., consolidating many web textures down to a few).
Kaze marks the Lofty Lamba Leaps level (tree-platforming area) as close to beta-ready, indicating broader beta-test progress beyond the hub area.

Kaze begins outlining a ‘mechanic’ boss fight concept (an antagonist who dislikes the player’s progress) and pins it to late-game progression: after Bowser 2 and after earning stars in later courses (he notes C12/C10 as gating areas).
He critiques the NES/8-bit art style trend as often chosen for cost rather than aesthetics, and says overuse has made it stale to him.
findings.quote: More often than not, people make games in that art style because it's cheap to do. Not because they think it looks good.

biobak.summary: Kaze describes Biobak’s role as a consistent second pass on his models—improving visual quality and simplifying texture sets (e.g., reducing too many texture variants into a cleaner, smaller set).
biobak.quote: Biobak goes over my models after I'm done, and makes them look a lot better.

zeina.summary: Zeina sends Kaze a new texture during the stream, and her in-progress Yoshi house asset is treated as a key blocker for finalizing how ‘homely’ and populated the village feels.

findings.summary: Sauraen provides a structured explanation of F3DEX3 occlusion planes (RSP vertex-side checks, CPU-side coefficient generation with clipping/rotation, and heuristic selection among candidates) and guides a step-by-step debug using manual coefficients and DMEM verification.

He outlines forward microcode feature tradeoffs: triangle snakes vs. a three-triangle command to free instruction memory, and an on-demand RDP material execution concept to avoid unnecessary texture loads for occluded/off-screen geometry.

memorable_quotes.context: A blunt, concrete release strategy framed as a direct response to expected Nintendo enforcement.

memorable_quotes.context: A candid design taste statement that doubles as critique of retro-aesthetic trends and cost-driven creativity.

memorable_quotes.context: A simple but revealing ‘iteration moment’ where a small decal change dramatically improves the feel/readability of the hub space.

key_stories.title: Occlusion planes debugging session with Sauraen
key_stories.summary: Kaze tries to integrate Sauraen’s occlusion planes to reclaim performance headroom for the Overworld/start area. The attempt turns into a live troubleshooting call: they validate data paths and memory, but the feature still doesn’t occlude, pushing the issue back to Sauraen for retesting and possibly revisiting assumptions/coefficient math.
key_stories.challenge: Occlusion planes “don’t seem to work at all,” blocking a major performance lever for higher-detail scenes.
key_stories.process: They discuss the full pipeline (RSP checks, CPU coefficient generation, heuristics selection), then attempt a minimal test by manually injecting ‘include everything’ coefficients, switching emulators, verifying DMEM/RSP memory contents, and checking display list placement/pointer-vs-data mistakes.
key_stories.outcome: The occlusion plane command/data reaches the RSP correctly, but occlusion still fails; Sauraen plans to retest on his end and update Kaze, while also floating future microcode optimizations.

key_stories.title: Designing Yoshi Village to feel lived-in (paths, flowers, campfire)
key_stories.summary: Kaze iterates toward a ‘homely’ hub by layering small environmental signals—paths, props, and a gathering point—rather than relying on overt themed architecture. The stream captures a clear before/after where a path decal and campfire seating transform the mood of the area.
key_stories.challenge: The village looks empty/sterile, and some legacy assets look ‘awful’ compared to newer work.
key_stories.process: He experiments with path decals, considers wells and flower gardens, reuses fireplaces from other courses, and adds seating logs; he also plans fruit baskets with actual fruit textures and waits on Zeina’s Yoshi house to anchor the space.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze shifts from disliking the area to enjoying it, calling it cozy and homely, and queues the rest as a structured task list for future streams.
key_stories.key_quote: I hated it first, now I kinda love it.

key_stories.title: Preempting a Nintendo takedown with a dual-build release plan
key_stories.summary: Kaze explicitly anticipates Nintendo enforcement soon after release and describes a pragmatic countermeasure: ship a Mario version and a non-Mario version. This story reveals how legal risk shapes technical priorities (custom protagonist) and production scheduling (parallel work while levels are reworked).
key_stories.challenge: Risk that Nintendo will demand removal of a Mario-branded build shortly after release.
key_stories.process: He plans to replace Mario with a custom character and publish both builds; if a takedown hits, the team can comply on the Mario build while keeping the alternate build available.
key_stories.outcome: A clear mitigation strategy that influences the development roadmap and asset priorities beyond purely creative goals.
key_stories.key_quote: So that when Nintendo... take this down, we can be like, fine, but there's another. Fuck you.

key_stories.title: Microcode roadmap: trading ‘clever’ features for future headroom
key_stories.summary: Sauraen and Kaze confront a classic optimization dilemma: triangle snakes save display-list bandwidth but consume instruction memory and now carry higher relative cost after recent RSP speedups. The conversation expands into a bigger idea—deferring material/texture loads until a triangle actually draws—suggesting the project’s performance ceiling may still move significantly.
key_stories.challenge: Instruction memory is nearly full, limiting further microcode improvements, while Kaze still needs more frame time to hit 60 FPS in heavy scenes.
key_stories.process: They compare expected gains from triangle snakes vs. an SP three-triangles command, estimate triangle counts (8–9k in heavy views), and explore an on-demand material execution scheme with toolchain implications and correctness risks.
key_stories.outcome: No immediate decision, but a documented set of next-step options and a shared understanding of constraints that can guide future engineering work and interview discussion.

open_questions.topic: Why exactly did occlusion planes fail despite correct DMEM data?
open_questions.context: They verified the occlusion-plane struct reaches RSP memory and the display list placement seems correct, yet nothing occludes; Sauraen suspects either coefficient mistakes or something subtly broken/assumed in the microcode/tooling path.
questions: When you later retested, what was the root cause—bad coefficients, an integration mistake, emulator behavior, or a bug/regression in the microcode?
What was the moment you realized ‘this is it’—and how did getting occlusion planes working change what you could build in the Overworld/start level?
Did you end up keeping the occlusion-plane coefficient generation on CPU, or did any part move toward RSP over time? Why?

open_questions.topic: Triangle snakes vs. new triangle commands (and what ‘performance headroom’ is worth)
open_questions.context: Sauraen notes triangle snakes are now comparatively slower against a faster baseline, and instruction memory is tight; alternatives like an SP three-triangles command could preserve some bandwidth savings while freeing space for other features.
questions: How did you decide whether to keep triangle snakes—what measurements or constraints ultimately mattered most (DMA/memory traffic, RSP time, tooling complexity, instruction-memory headroom)?
What other ‘next microcode features’ were most tempting once you realized instruction memory was the limiting factor?
If you could only keep one microcode ‘clever trick,’ which would it be and why?

open_questions.topic: On-demand material/texture-load execution idea and its pipeline cost
open_questions.context: Sauraen proposes deferring RDP material command blocks until a triangle actually draws, potentially saving large texture-load costs for occluded/off-screen objects, but at the price of state-management complexity and re-export/tooling changes.
questions: Did you prototype the deferred-material idea, and if so, what broke first: correctness (state/revert display lists), tooling, or the actual savings being smaller than expected?
How did you weigh ‘big potential savings’ against the reality that it might force re-exporting or retooling large portions of the game?
In practice, what ended up being the biggest RDP-time killers in RTYI scenes: texture loads, overdraw, combine mode changes, or something else?

open_questions.topic: Dual-build release strategy and the custom-character plan
open_questions.context: Kaze states an intent to ship versions with and without Mario to survive an expected Nintendo takedown, implying a major character/animation/branding effort and a release/communications plan.
questions: What did ‘replacing Mario’ concretely require in your engine and content pipeline (animations, hitboxes, camera assumptions, voice/sound hooks, UI)?
How did you plan to communicate the two-build approach to players without making the project easier to target legally?
Did the expectation of a takedown change any creative decisions—like how explicit Mario iconography could be in levels, UI, or story?
Looking back, was the dual-build plan mainly a deterrent, a practical fallback, or both?

open_questions.topic: The ‘mechanic’ boss fight concept and late-game placement
open_questions.context: Kaze notes a ‘mechanic boss fight’ idea—an antagonist reacting to player progress—and tentatively places it after Bowser 2 and after some stars in later courses (C10/C12).
questions: Who is the ‘mechanic’ in the story, and what does ‘she doesn’t like how much progress you’ve been making’ mean narratively?
What was the intended core mechanic of the fight—how would it feel distinct from other bosses and from Mario 64’s Bowser structure?
Why place it after Bowser 2 specifically—what pacing or skill assumptions made that the right moment?
